addressleaf.section:
To the right woorshipfull S
r
John Conway knight Governo
r
of
e towne of Ostend

page.lettertext:
S
r
, the Ennemie hath bin about
Bommel,
and hath
taken
Brakell
and
Poieroyen,
and endevoured to
force a passage over
e Wael by
Herwijren,
but hath
bin valiantly repulsed by
Captaine Edmond
.
Howbeit his forces increase every houre, and heere is
advertisment come,
at
e
Duke
himself doth purpose
to be there in person. So that now e he will invade
Umbilic
u
Reip. For if
e passage be wonne, we
may bidde farewell to
Leerdam,
Asperen,
Cullenborch
and
Vianen,
and to
Utrecht
shortly after: wherof
yow knowe
e c
o
sequence. The c
o
sideration heerof
doth so troble
e counsell, and
e Governo
rs
heere, as
nothing more. For
e greatest part of all their forces
are w
t
Schincke,
whome
e Ennemie doth so busie,
as w
t
out
e apparant losse of
e Province of
Guelders
he can hardly spare us any c
o
panies. And it fareth
a like w
t
Count William
in
Friseland,
to whome
Verdugo
doth give his handes full: so as heere in
these quarters, where
e Ennemie doth assault us so
mightily, we nether have men, nor meanes to raise
any. In w
ch
respect I doe finde
e whole contrey in
a mervelous perplexitie: and therupp
o
they have writ-
ten to yo
w
, to
e
Brill,
and to
Flushing
for some pre-
sent assistance. And though I am moved by them
to solicite
e request, yet I am a great deale more
moved, in regard of my duty to her
Ma
tie
and
e
imminent daunger w
ch
is like to ensewe. Whereupp
o
considering w
at
companies have bin lately sent out of
England
unto yo
w
, and also considering
at
e Ennemie
doth not presse yo
w
so hardly, as he hath done heeretofore,
if yo
w
could send them two companies to serve their
turne for
e time, there is no dout but yo
r
service
therein will be well accepted of her Ma
tie
. As on
e
other side if any notable losse should come to these
Contreis, and it shall appeere by good evidence that
they might have had some succo
r
from
e Garrison townes,
I leave to yo
r
wisdome to c
o
sider uppon whome
e
reproche will redound, and
e outcries of this people.
I doe not dout but fewer wordes might have served
in this mater, but yet
e instance w
ch
is used heere,
and their necessitie is so great, as I can not but
rec
o
mend it most effectually unto yo
w
, whiche I doe
assure my self
at
yo
w
will not otherwise c
o
strue,
them very frindly, and to
e better part.
Hage. 16 Julij 89 Yo
r
most assured in
any thing Tho. Bodley.
S
r
, I knowe it is needeles to intreat
yo
w
to make muche of this bearer
M
r
Matrut
. For in truth he doth deserve it
for his good affection towardes all o
r
nation, and particularly to yo
w
, of whome
his report to
e Councell hath bin honorable and very respective.
